title: Non-Spatial Random Forest Models
text: tutorial demonstrates fit interpret non-spatial random forest models using spatialRF package. ’ll learn explore spatial data, find promising variable interactions, train models, evaluate performance, understand variable importance. ’re interested addressing spatial autocorrelation model residuals, see Spatial Random Forest Models tutorial.

title: Non-Spatial Random Forest Models
text: following libraries required tutorial. Many functions package also support parallelization backend speed-execution. package includes example dataset plants_df plant species richness predictors 227 ecoregions Americas. object plants_distance matrix geographical distances ecoregions. figure shows response variable richness_species_vascular space.  predictors, stored plants_predictors represent diverse factors may influence plant richness sampling bias, area ecoregion, climatic variables, human presence impact, topography, geographical fragmentation, features neighbors ecoregion. figure shows scatterplots response variable (y axis) predictor (x axis).  function plot_training_df_moran() shows spatial autocorrelation response predictors across different distance thresholds. Low Moran’s p-values equal larger 0.05 indicate spatial autocorrelation given variable distance threshold.
code: library(spatialRF) library(ggplot2) library(dplyr) library(DT) library(rnaturalearth) library(rnaturalearthdata) library(randomForestExplainer) library(parallel) library(patchwork) cluster <- parallel::makeCluster(   2, #parallel::detectCores() - 1,   type = "PSOCK" ) data(   plants_df,         #training data frame   plants_response,   #response name   plants_predictors, #predictors names   plants_distance,   #distance matrix in km   plants_xy          #case coordinates of plants_df   )  #distance thresholds (same units as plants_distance, km) #used to assess spatial correlation at different distances distance_thresholds <- c(10, 100, 1000, 2000, 4000, 8000)  #a pretty color palette colors <- grDevices::hcl.colors(     n = 100,     palette = "Zissou 1"     ) spatialRF::plot_training_df(   data = plants_df,   dependent.variable.name = plants_response,   predictor.variable.names = plants_predictors,   point.color = colors,   ncol = 3   ) spatialRF::plot_training_df_moran(   data = plants_df,   dependent.variable.name = plants_response,   predictor.variable.names = plants_predictors,   distance.matrix = plants_distance,   distance.thresholds = distance_thresholds,   fill.color = colors )

title: Non-Spatial Random Forest Models
text: function rf_tuning() optimizes values three critical Random Forest hyperparameters via spatial cross-validation: num.trees: number regression trees forest. mtry: number variables choose tree split. min.node.size: minimum number cases terminal node. function returns tuned model tuning finds solution better original model. tuning results can accessed plot_tuning().
code: m <- rf_tuning(   model = m,   xy = plants_xy,   repetitions = 30,   num.trees = c(100, 200, 300),   mtry = c(2, 4, 8),   min.node.size = c(5, 10, 20),   cluster = cluster,   verbose = TRUE ) spatialRF::plot_tuning(   model = m,   point.color = colors )

title: Non-Spatial Random Forest Models
text: function rf_evaluate() provides honest performance scores based spatial cross-validation. function separates data spatially independent training testing folds. function creates m$evaluation several objects summarize spatial cross-validation results. slot “spatial.folds”, produced make_spatial_folds(), contains indices training testing cases cross-validation repetition. maps show two sets training testing folds.  information available new slot can accessed functions print_evaluation(), plot_evaluation(), get_evaluation().  Full performance model trained full dataset. Training performance model trained training folds. Testing performance model testing folds. median, median absolute deviation (MAD), minimum, maximum R-squared values testing folds can printed print_evaluation().
code: m <- spatialRF::rf_evaluate(   model = m,   xy = plants_xy,           #data coordinates   repetitions = 30,         #number of spatial folds   training.fraction = 0.75, #training data fraction on each fold   metrics = "r.squared",   cluster = cluster,   verbose = FALSE ) names(m$evaluation) #> [1] "metrics"           "training.fraction" "spatial.folds"     #> [4] "per.fold"          "per.fold.long"     "per.model"         #> [7] "aggregated" spatialRF::plot_evaluation(   model = m,   fill.color = colors,   notch = FALSE   ) spatialRF::print_evaluation(m) #>  #> Spatial evaluation  #>   - Training fraction:             0.75 #>   - Spatial folds:                 29 #>  #>     Metric Median   MAD Minimum Maximum #>  r.squared  0.429 0.151   0.144   0.655

title: Spatial Random Forest Models
text: tutorial demonstrates address spatial autocorrelation random forest model residuals using spatialRF package. Spatial autocorrelation occurs model residuals nearby locations similar expected chance, violating assumption independence potentially leading inflated performance metrics biased variable importance scores. rf_spatial() function addresses issue incorporating spatial predictors (Moran’s Eigenvector Maps) capture spatial structure explained environmental predictors alone. introduction non-spatial random forest modeling spatialRF, see Non-Spatial Random Forest Models tutorial.

what: Using spatial predictors in other models
title: Spatial Random Forest Models
text: Spatial predictors spatialRF can used modeling method. workflow: generate MEMs, rank Moran’s , add sequentially residual autocorrelation resolved.  Residuals show spatial autocorrelation. Let’s add MEMs sequentially:  Compare models: Adding spatial predictors eliminated autocorrelation improving model fit.
code: #generate and rank MEMs mems <- spatialRF::mem_multithreshold(   distance.matrix = plants_distance,   distance.thresholds = distance_thresholds )  ranked <- spatialRF::rank_spatial_predictors(   distance.matrix = plants_distance,   spatial.predictors.df = mems,   ranking.method = "moran" )  mems <- mems[, ranked$ranking] #prepare scaled data plants_df.scaled <- plants_df |>    scale() |>    as.data.frame()  #fit non-spatial model m1 <- lm(   richness_species_vascular ~ human_population + climate_bio1_average +     climate_hypervolume + human_footprint_average,   data = plants_df.scaled )  #check autocorrelation m1.moran <- spatialRF::moran(   x = residuals(m1),   distance.matrix = plants_distance,   verbose = FALSE )  m1.moran$plot #combine data with MEMs plants_df.mem <- cbind(plants_df.scaled, mems) |> scale() |> as.data.frame()  #add MEMs until autocorrelation resolved spatial_predictors <- character(0)  for(i in seq_along(mems)){    spatial_predictors <- c(spatial_predictors, names(mems)[i])    formula_i <- reformulate(     c(       "human_population",        "climate_bio1_average",       "climate_hypervolume",        "human_footprint_average",       spatial_predictors       ),     response = plants_response   )    m2 <- lm(     formula = formula_i,      data = plants_df.mem     )    m2.moran <- spatialRF::moran(     x = residuals(m2),     distance.matrix = plants_distance,     verbose = FALSE   )    if(m2.moran$test$interpretation == "No spatial correlation") break }  m2.moran$plot

title: spatialRF: Easy Spatial Regression with Random Forest
text: package spatialRF trains explanatory spatial regression models combining Random Forest spatial predictors help model reduce spatial autocorrelation residuals return honest variable importance scores. package designed minimize code required fit spatial model training dataset, names response predictors, distance matrix, shown mock-call . spatialRF uses fast efficient ranger package hood (Wright Ziegler 2017), please, cite ranger package using spatialRF! package also provides tools identify potentially interesting variable interactions, tune random forest hyperparameters, assess model performance spatially independent data folds, examine resulting models via importance plots, response curves, response surfaces. However, several things package : Predict model results raster data. Predict model different place different spatial structure. Work “big data”, whatever means. Imputation extrapolation (can done, models based spatial predictors hardly transferable). Take temporal autocorrelation account.
code: m <- spatialRF::rf_spatial(   data = df,   dependent.variable.name = "response",   predictor.variable.names = c("pred1", "pred2", ..., "predN"),   distance.matrix = distance_matrix   )

title: spatialRF: Easy Spatial Regression with Random Forest
text: spatialRF designed work : Data frames: tibbles sf dataframes fully supported. Continuous responses: binomial responses partially supported (however, spatial models hardly work ), categorical factor responses . Small data: spatial modelling operations RAM-hungry, maximum number rows must somewhere 5000 10000, end depends available RAM. Must free NA. Columns near-zero variance. don’t want near-zero variance columns data anyway.

title: Area under the ROC curve — auc
text: o Numeric vector actual binary labels (0 1). Must length p. p Numeric vector predicted probabilities (typically 0 1). Must length o.

text: Numeric value 0 1 representing AUC. Higher values indicate better classification performance, 0.5 indicating random performance 1.0 indicating perfect classification.

text: Filters predictors using sequential evaluation pairwise correlations. Predictors ranked user preference (column order) evaluated sequentially. candidate added selected pool maximum absolute correlation already-selected predictors exceed threshold.

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Pearson correlation — auto_cor
code: auto_cor(   x = NULL,   preference.order = NULL,   cor.threshold = 0.5,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Pearson correlation — auto_cor
text: x Data frame predictors, variable_selection object auto_vif(). Default: NULL. preference.order Character vector specifying variable preference order. need include variables x. NULL, column order used. Default: NULL. cor.threshold Numeric 0 1 (recommended: 0.5 0.9). Maximum allowed absolute Pearson correlation selected variables. Default: 0.50 verbose Logical. TRUE, prints messages operations removed variables. Default: TRUE

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Pearson correlation — auto_cor
text: List class variable_selection containing: cor: Correlation matrix selected variables (2+ variables selected). selected.variables: Character vector selected variable names. selected.variables.df: Data frame containing selected variables.

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Pearson correlation — auto_cor
text: algorithm follows steps: Rank predictors preference.order (use column order NULL). Initialize selection pool first predictor. remaining candidate: Compute maximum absolute correlation selected predictors. max correlation equal lower cor.threshold, add selected pool. Otherwise, skip candidate. Return selected predictors. Data cleaning: Variables preference.order found colnames(x) silently removed. Non-numeric columns removed warning. Rows NA values removed via na.omit(). Zero-variance columns trigger warning removed. function can chained auto_vif() pipes (see examples).

what: Multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — auto_vif
title: Multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — auto_vif
text: Filters predictors using sequential evaluation variance inflation factors. Predictors ranked user preference (column order) evaluated sequentially. candidate added selected pool maximum VIF predictors (candidate plus already-selected) exceed threshold.

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — auto_vif
code: auto_vif(x = NULL, preference.order = NULL, vif.threshold = 5, verbose = TRUE)

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — auto_vif
text: x Data frame predictors, variable_selection object auto_cor(). Default: NULL. preference.order Character vector specifying variable preference order. need include variables x. NULL, column order used. Default: NULL. vif.threshold Numeric (recommended: 2.5 10). Maximum allowed VIF among selected variables. Higher values allow collinearity. Default: 5. verbose Logical. TRUE, prints messages operations removed variables. Default: TRUE

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — auto_vif
text: List class variable_selection containing: vif: Data frame selected variable names VIF scores. selected.variables: Character vector selected variable names. selected.variables.df: Data frame containing selected variables.

title: Multicollinearity reduction via Variance Inflation Factor — auto_vif
text: algorithm follows steps: Rank predictors preference.order (use column order NULL). Initialize selection pool first predictor. remaining candidate: Compute VIF candidate plus selected predictors. max VIF equal lower vif.threshold, add candidate selected pool. Otherwise, skip candidate. Return selected predictors VIF values. Data cleaning: Variables preference.order found colnames(x) silently removed. Non-numeric columns removed warning. Rows NA values removed via na.omit(). Zero-variance columns trigger warning removed. function can chained auto_cor() pipes (see examples).

what: Create a Beowulf cluster for parallel computing — beowulf_cluster
title: Create a Beowulf cluster for parallel computing — beowulf_cluster
text: Creates Beowulf cluster configuration machine IPs, core counts, user credentials.

title: Create a Beowulf cluster for parallel computing — beowulf_cluster
code: beowulf_cluster(   cluster.ips = NULL,   cluster.cores = NULL,   cluster.user = Sys.info()[["user"]],   cluster.port = "11000",   outfile = NULL )

title: Create a Beowulf cluster for parallel computing — beowulf_cluster
text: cluster.ips Character vector machine IP addresses cluster. first IP main node (typically machine running code). Default: NULL. cluster.cores Integer vector core counts machine. Must match length cluster.ips. Default: NULL. cluster.user Character string user name across machines. Default: current system user. cluster.port Character string specifying communication port. Default: "11000". outfile Character string NULL. Path append worker messages, "" print console, NULL (default) /dev/null (Linux) nul: (Windows).

title: Create a Beowulf cluster for parallel computing — beowulf_cluster
text: Cluster object created parallel::makeCluster(), ready registration doParallel::registerDoParallel().

title: Create a Beowulf cluster for parallel computing — beowulf_cluster
text: Network requirements: Firewalls machines must allow traffic specified port. Usage workflow: Create cluster function Register doParallel::registerDoParallel() Run parallelized code (e.g., foreach loops) Stop cluster parallel::stopCluster()

title: Create a Beowulf cluster for parallel computing — beowulf_cluster
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Create cluster with 3 machines beowulf.cluster <- beowulf_cluster(   cluster.ips = c(     "192.168.1.10",  # main node     "192.168.1.11",     "192.168.1.12"   ),   cluster.cores = c(7, 4, 4),   cluster.user = "username",   cluster.port = "11000" )  # Register cluster for parallel processing doParallel::registerDoParallel(cl = beowulf.cluster)  # Run parallelized code (e.g., foreach loop) # your_parallel_code_here  # Stop cluster when done parallel::stopCluster(cl = beowulf.cluster) } # }

what: Generate case weights for imbalanced binary data — case_weights
title: Generate case weights for imbalanced binary data — case_weights
text: Generates case weights balance binary response variables use ranger models. Used internally rf().

title: Generate case weights for imbalanced binary data — case_weights
code: case_weights(data = NULL, dependent.variable.name = NULL)

title: Generate case weights for imbalanced binary data — case_weights
text: data Data frame containing response variable. Default: NULL. dependent.variable.name Character string specifying response variable name. Must column data. Default: NULL.

title: Generate case weights for imbalanced binary data — case_weights
text: Numeric vector length nrow(data) case weights. weight inverse class frequency: 1/n_zeros 0s 1/n_ones 1s.

title: Generate case weights for imbalanced binary data — case_weights
text: weighting scheme assigns higher weights minority class balance training: Cases value 0: weight = 1 / n_zeros Cases value 1: weight = 1 / n_ones ensures classes contribute equally model training regardless class imbalance.

title: Generate case weights for imbalanced binary data — case_weights
code: # Imbalanced dataset: 3 zeros, 2 ones weights <- case_weights(   data = data.frame(     response = c(0, 0, 0, 1, 1)   ),   dependent.variable.name = "response" )  weights #> [1] 0.3333333 0.3333333 0.3333333 0.5000000 0.5000000 # Returns: 0.333, 0.333, 0.333, 0.5, 0.5 # Zeros get weight 1/3, ones get weight 1/2

what: Default distance thresholds for spatial predictors — default_distance_thresholds
title: Default distance thresholds for spatial predictors — default_distance_thresholds
text: Generates four evenly-spaced distance thresholds spatial predictor generation, ranging 0 half maximum distance matrix.

title: Default distance thresholds for spatial predictors — default_distance_thresholds
code: default_distance_thresholds(distance.matrix = NULL)

title: Default distance thresholds for spatial predictors — default_distance_thresholds
text: distance.matrix Numeric distance matrix (typically square symmetric). Default: NULL.

title: Default distance thresholds for spatial predictors — default_distance_thresholds
text: Numeric vector length 4 distance thresholds (floored integers).

title: Default distance thresholds for spatial predictors — default_distance_thresholds
text: maximum threshold set half maximum distance avoid spatial predictors based distances large capture meaningful spatial autocorrelation. four thresholds evenly spaced using seq() length.= 4.

title: Default distance thresholds for spatial predictors — default_distance_thresholds
code: data(plants_distance)  thresholds <- default_distance_thresholds(   distance.matrix = plants_distance )  thresholds #> [1]    0 2399 4798 7198 # Example output: c(0, 3333, 6666, 10000) # Four evenly-spaced thresholds from 0 to max(plants_distance)/2

what: Convert VIF values to data frame — .vif_to_df
title: Convert VIF values to data frame — .vif_to_df
text: Computes variance inflation factors variables data frame returns tidy format, sorted VIF descending order.

title: Convert VIF values to data frame — .vif_to_df
code: .vif_to_df(x)

title: Convert VIF values to data frame — .vif_to_df
text: x Data frame numeric predictors compute VIF values.

title: Convert VIF values to data frame — .vif_to_df
text: Data frame two columns: variable (character, variable names) vif (numeric, VIF scores), sorted VIF descending order.

title: Double-center a distance matrix — double_center_distance_matrix
text: Double-centers distance matrix converting weights centering zero row column means. Required computing Moran's Eigenvector Maps.

title: Double-center a distance matrix — double_center_distance_matrix
code: double_center_distance_matrix(distance.matrix = NULL, distance.threshold = 0)

title: Double-center a distance matrix — double_center_distance_matrix
text: distance.matrix Numeric distance matrix. Default: NULL. distance.threshold Numeric distance threshold weight calculation. Distances threshold set 0 weighting. Default: 0.

title: Double-center a distance matrix — double_center_distance_matrix
text: Double-centered numeric matrix dimensions distance.matrix. matrix row means column means zero.

title: Double-center a distance matrix — double_center_distance_matrix
text: Double-centering performed two steps: Convert distances weights using weights_from_distance_matrix() Center matrix: subtract row means, subtract column means, add grand mean resulting matrix symmetric zero row column means, suitable Moran's Eigenvector Maps computation.

title: Double-center a distance matrix — double_center_distance_matrix
code: data(plants_distance)  # Double-center the distance matrix centered <- double_center_distance_matrix(   distance.matrix = plants_distance )  # Verify row means are zero head(rowMeans(centered)) #>             1             2             3             4             5  #> -1.184503e-19  1.150114e-18  1.299132e-19  9.361393e-19  1.085157e-18  #>             6  #>  2.445425e-19   # Verify column means are zero head(colMeans(centered)) #>            1            2            3            4            5            6  #> 2.025118e-19 2.598264e-19 1.108083e-19 2.502740e-19 3.668138e-19 5.234738e-19

title: Remove redundant spatial predictors — filter_spatial_predictors
text: Removes spatial predictors highly correlated spatial predictors non-spatial predictors. Particularly useful using multiple distance thresholds produce correlated spatial predictors.

title: Remove redundant spatial predictors — filter_spatial_predictors
code: filter_spatial_predictors(   data = NULL,   predictor.variable.names = NULL,   spatial.predictors.df = NULL,   cor.threshold = 0.5 )

title: Remove redundant spatial predictors — filter_spatial_predictors
text: data Data frame containing predictor variables. Default: NULL. predictor.variable.names Character vector non-spatial predictor names. Must match column names data. Can also variable_selection object. Default: NULL. spatial.predictors.df Data frame spatial predictors (e.g., mem_multithreshold()). Default: NULL. cor.threshold Numeric 0 1 (recommended: 0.5 0.75). Maximum allowed absolute Pearson correlation. Default: 0.50.

title: Remove redundant spatial predictors — filter_spatial_predictors
text: Data frame containing spatial predictors correlations cor.threshold (among non-spatial predictors).

title: Remove redundant spatial predictors — filter_spatial_predictors
text: Filtering performed two steps: Remove spatial predictors correlated (using auto_cor()) Remove spatial predictors correlated non-spatial predictors two-step process ensures retained spatial predictors independent environmental predictors, improving model interpretability reducing multicollinearity.

title: Remove redundant spatial predictors — filter_spatial_predictors
code: data(   plants_df,   plants_predictors,   plants_distance )  # Generate spatial predictors using multiple distance thresholds mem.df <- mem_multithreshold(   distance.matrix = plants_distance,   distance.thresholds = c(0, 1000) )  # Filter spatial predictors to remove redundancy # Removes spatial predictors correlated > 0.50 with each other # or with environmental predictors spatial.predictors.filtered <- filter_spatial_predictors(   data = plants_df,   predictor.variable.names = plants_predictors,   spatial.predictors.df = mem.df,   cor.threshold = 0.50 )  # Check dimensions ncol(mem.df)  # original number #> [1] 160 ncol(spatial.predictors.filtered)  # after filtering #> [1] 154

title: Create spatially independent training and testing folds — make_spatial_fold
text: data Data frame containing response variable predictors. Required binary response variables. dependent.variable.name Character string name response variable. Must column name data. Required binary response variables. xy.Single-row data frame columns "x" (longitude), "y" (latitude), "id" (record identifier). Defines focal point buffer grows. xy Data frame columns "x" (longitude), "y" (latitude), "id" (record identifier). Contains spatial coordinates dataset. distance.step.x Numeric value specifying buffer growth increment along x-axis. Default: NULL (automatically set 1/1000th x-coordinate range). distance.step.y Numeric value specifying buffer growth increment along y-axis. title: Create spatially independent training and testing folds — make_spatial_fold
text: function creates spatially independent training testing folds spatial cross-validation. algorithm works follows: Starts small rectangular buffer centered focal point (xy.) Grows buffer incrementally distance.step.x distance.step.y Continues growing buffer contains desired number records (training.fraction * total records) Assigns records inside buffer training records outside testing Special handling binary response variables: data dependent.variable.name provided response binary (0/1), function ensures training.fraction applies number presences (1s), total records. prevents imbalanced sampling presence-absence models.

text: data Data frame containing response variable predictors. Required binary response variables. dependent.variable.name Character string name response variable. Must column name data. text: function creates multiple spatially independent folds spatial cross-validation calling make_spatial_fold() row xy.selected. fold created growing rectangular buffer corresponding focal point desired training.fraction achieved. Parallel execution: function uses parallel processing speed fold creation. can control parallelization n.cores provide pre-configured cluster object. title: Create multiple spatially independent training and testing folds — make_spatial_folds
code: data(plants_df, plants_xy)  # Thin to 10 focal points to speed up example xy.thin <- thinning_til_n(   xy = plants_xy,   n = 10 )  # Create spatial folds centered on the 10 thinned points folds <- make_spatial_folds(   xy.selected = xy.thin,   xy = plants_xy,   distance.step.x = 0.05,   training.fraction = 0.6,   n.cores = 1 )  # Each element is a fold with training and testing indices length(folds)  # 10 folds #> [1] 10 names(folds[[1]])  # "training" and "testing" #> [1] "training" "testing"   # Visualize first fold (training = red, testing = blue, center = black) if (interactive()) {   plot(plants_xy[c("x", "y")], type = "n", xlab = "", ylab = "")   points(plants_xy[folds[[1]]$training, c("x", "y")], col = "red4", pch = 15)   points(plants_xy[folds[[1]]$testing, c("x", "y")], col = "blue4", pch = 15)   points(     plants_xy[folds[[1]]$training[1], c("x", "y")],     col = "black",     pch = 15,     cex = 2   ) }

text: Computes Moran's Eigenvector Maps (MEMs) distance matrix. Returns eigenvectors positive spatial autocorrelation, capture broad medium-scale spatial patterns.

title: Compute Moran's Eigenvector Maps from distance matrix — mem
code: mem(distance.matrix = NULL, distance.threshold = 0, colnames.prefix = "mem")

title: Compute Moran's Eigenvector Maps from distance matrix — mem
text: distance.matrix Numeric distance matrix spatial locations. distance.threshold Numeric value specifying maximum distance spatial neighbors. Distances threshold set zero. Default: 0 (thresholding). colnames.prefix Character string used prefix column names output. Default: "mem".

title: Compute Moran's Eigenvector Maps from distance matrix — mem
text: Data frame column MEM (spatial predictor) representing different scale spatial pattern. Columns named pattern <prefix>_<number> (e.g., "mem_1", "mem_2").

title: Compute Moran's Eigenvector Maps from distance matrix — mem
text: Moran's Eigenvector Maps (MEMs) spatial variables represent spatial structures different scales. function creates MEMs following steps: Double-centers distance matrix using double_center_distance_matrix() Computes eigenvectors eigenvalues using base::eigen() Normalizes eigenvalues dividing maximum absolute eigenvalue Selects eigenvectors positive normalized eigenvalues Positive vs. negative eigenvalues: Eigenvectors positive eigenvalues represent positive spatial autocorrelation (nearby locations similar), capturing broad medium-scale spatial patterns. Eigenvectors negative eigenvalues represent negative spatial autocorrelation (nearby locations dissimilar) excluded. returned MEMs ordered eigenvalue magnitude, first columns capturing broadest spatial patterns. MEMs used spatial predictors rf_spatial() account spatial autocorrelation model residuals.

title: Compute Moran's Eigenvector Maps from distance matrix — mem

Default: NULL (automatically computed default_distance_thresholds()). max.spatial.predictors Integer specifying maximum number spatial predictors return. total number MEMs exceeds value, first max.spatial.predictors columns returned. Default: NULL (limit).

title: Compute Moran's Eigenvector Maps across multiple distance thresholds — mem_multithreshold
text: Data frame one row per observation (matching distance.matrix dimensions) columns representing MEMs different distance thresholds. Column names follow pattern spatial_predictor_<threshold>_<number> (e.g., "spatial_predictor_0_1", "spatial_predictor_1000_2").

title: Compute Moran's Eigenvector Maps across multiple distance thresholds — mem_multithreshold
text: function generates spatial predictors multiple spatial scales computing MEMs different distance thresholds. Different thresholds capture spatial patterns different scales: Smaller thresholds (e.g., 0) capture fine-scale spatial patterns Larger thresholds capture broad-scale spatial patterns Algorithm: distance threshold, calls mem() compute MEMs mem() call applies threshold, double-centers matrix, extracts positive eigenvectors Combines MEMs single data frame Optionally limits total number predictors max.spatial.predictors resulting MEMs used spatial predictors rf_spatial() model spatial autocorrelation multiple scales simultaneously.

what: Moran's I test for spatial autocorrelation — moran
title: Moran's I test for spatial autocorrelation — moran
text: Computes Moran's , measure spatial autocorrelation tests whether values similar (positive autocorrelation) dissimilar (negative autocorrelation) among spatial neighbors expected chance.

title: Moran's I test for spatial autocorrelation — moran
code: moran(   x = NULL,   distance.matrix = NULL,   distance.threshold = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Moran's I test for spatial autocorrelation — moran
text: x Numeric vector test spatial autocorrelation. Typically model residuals response variable. distance.matrix Numeric distance matrix observations. Must number rows length x. distance.threshold Numeric value specifying maximum distance spatial neighbors. Distances threshold set zero weighting. Default: NULL (automatically set 0, meaning thresholding). verbose Logical. TRUE, displays Moran's scatterplot. Default: TRUE.

title: Moran's I test for spatial autocorrelation — moran
text: List class "moran" three elements: test: Data frame containing: distance.threshold: distance threshold used moran..null: Expected Moran's null hypothesis spatial autocorrelation moran.: Observed Moran's statistic p.value: Two-tailed p-value normal approximation interpretation: Text interpretation result plot: ggplot object showing Moran's scatterplot (values vs. spatial lag values linear fit). plot.df: Data frame columns x (original values) x.lag (spatially lagged values) used generate plot.

title: Moran's I test for spatial autocorrelation — moran
text: Moran's measure spatial autocorrelation quantifies degree nearby observations similar values. statistic ranges approximately -1 +1: Positive values: Similar values cluster together (positive spatial autocorrelation) Values near zero: Random spatial pattern (spatial autocorrelation) Negative values: Dissimilar values adjacent (negative spatial autocorrelation, rare practice) Statistical testing: function compares observed Moran's expected value null hypothesis spatial autocorrelation (EI = -1/(n-1)). p-value computed using normal approximation. Results interpreted 0.05 significance level. Moran's scatterplot: plot shows original values (x-axis) spatially lagged values (y-axis). slope fitted line approximates Moran's . Points quadrants III indicate positive spatial autocorrelation; points quadrants II IV indicate negative spatial autocorrelation. implementation inspired Moran.() function ape package.

title: Moran's I test for spatial autocorrelation — moran
code: data(plants_df, plants_distance, plants_response)  # Test for spatial autocorrelation in response variable moran_test <- moran(   x = plants_df[[plants_response]],   distance.matrix = plants_distance,   distance.threshold = 1000 )   # View test results moran_test$test #>   distance.threshold moran.i.null   moran.i p.value #> 1               1000 -0.004424779 0.2588432       0 #>                 interpretation #> 1 Positive spatial correlation  # Access components moran_test$test$moran.i  # Observed Moran's I #> [1] 0.2588432 moran_test$test$p.value  # P-value #> [1] 0 moran_test$test$interpretation  # Text interpretation #> [1] "Positive spatial correlation"

title: Moran's I test across multiple distance thresholds — moran_multithreshold
text: function applies moran() multiple distance thresholds explore spatial autocorrelation different spatial scales. multi-scale approach valuable several reasons: Scale exploration: Different processes may operate different spatial scales. Testing multiple thresholds reveals scale(s) spatial autocorrelation strongest. Optimal neighborhood definition: Identifies distance threshold best captures spatial structure data. Uncertainty assessment: Spatial neighborhoods often uncertain ecological spatial data. Testing multiple thresholds accounts uncertainty. Interpreting results: plot shows Moran's values across distance thresholds. Peaks Moran's indicate spatial scales autocorrelation strongest. max.moran max.moran.distance.threshold values identify optimal scale. Significant results (p equal lower 0.05) indicate spatial autocorrelation particular scale. function commonly used : Detect spatial autocorrelation model residuals multiple scales Determine appropriate distance thresholds generating spatial predictors mem_multithreshold() Assess whether spatial patterns vary across scales

what: Compute optimization scores for spatial predictor selection — optimization_function
title: Compute optimization scores for spatial predictor selection — optimization_function
text: Computes optimization scores candidate spatial predictor sets using either "moran." "p.value" method. Higher scores indicate better trade-offs spatial autocorrelation reduction, model performance, parsimony.

title: Compute optimization scores for spatial predictor selection — optimization_function
code: optimization_function(   x = NULL,   weight.r.squared = NULL,   weight.penalization.n.predictors = NULL,   optimization.method = "moran.i" )

title: Compute optimization scores for spatial predictor selection — optimization_function
text: x Data frame containing optimization metrics candidate spatial predictor sets. Generated internally select_spatial_predictors_sequential() select_spatial_predictors_recursive(). Must include columns: moran., r.squared, penalization.per.variable, p.value.binary ("p.value" method). weight.r.squared Numeric value 0 1 specifying weight R-squared optimization score. Higher values prioritize model performance. weight.penalization.n.predictors Numeric value 0 1 specifying weight penalizing number spatial predictors. Higher values favor parsimonious models. optimization.method Character string specifying optimization method: "moran." (default) "p.value". Default: "moran.".

title: Compute optimization scores for spatial predictor selection — optimization_function
text: Numeric vector optimization scores, one per row x. Higher scores indicate better solutions. values rescaled 0 1 comparability.

title: Compute optimization scores for spatial predictor selection — optimization_function
text: function balances three objectives selecting spatial predictors: Reduce spatial autocorrelation: Maximize 1 - Moran's minimize residual spatial autocorrelation Maintain model performance: Account model R-squared Favor parsimony: Penalize models many spatial predictors Optimization methods: "moran." method computes: score = (1 - Moran's ) + w1 × R² - w2 × penalization components rescaled range 0 1, w1 = weight.r.squared, w2 = weight.penalization.n.predictors. "p.value" method computes: score = max(1 - Moran's , binary p-value) + w1 × R² - w2 × penalization binary p-value 1 p equal lower 0.05 (significant spatial autocorrelation), 0 otherwise. Practical differences: "moran." method uses continuous Moran's values typically selects spatial predictors achieve lower spatial autocorrelation "p.value" method uses binary significance thresholds typically selects fewer predictors, stopping spatial autocorrelation becomes non-significant optimal model one highest optimization score.

title: Compute optimization scores for spatial predictor selection — optimization_function
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # This function is typically called internally during spatial predictor selection # Example showing the structure of input data:  # Simulated optimization data frame opt_data <- data.frame(   moran.i = c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2, 0.15),   r.squared = c(0.6, 0.65, 0.68, 0.69),   penalization.per.variable = c(0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4),   p.value.binary = c(0, 0, 1, 1) )  # Compute optimization scores scores_moran <- optimization_function(   x = opt_data,   weight.r.squared = 0.5,   weight.penalization.n.predictors = 0.5,   optimization.method = "moran.i" )  # Compare methods scores_pvalue <- optimization_function(   x = opt_data,   weight.r.squared = 0.5,   weight.penalization.n.predictors = 0.5,   optimization.method = "p.value" )  # Higher score indicates better solution which.max(scores_moran) which.max(scores_pvalue) } # }

title: Compute Principal Component Analysis — pca
text: function performs Principal Component Analysis (PCA) create uncorrelated linear combinations original variables. PCA process: Removes columns zero variance (constant values) Scales remaining variables mean = 0 standard deviation = 1 Computes principal components using singular value decomposition Returns principal components ordered decreasing variance explained Usage spatial analysis: PCA useful dimension reduction working spatial distance matrices multiple correlated spatial predictors. creates orthogonal (uncorrelated) variables capture main patterns variation reducing dimensionality. spatial modeling rf_spatial(), principal components distance matrices can serve alternative spatial predictors Moran's Eigenvector Maps (MEMs). Use pca_multithreshold() compute PCA across multiple distance thresholds multi-scale spatial modeling.

title: Compute Principal Component Analysis at multiple distance thresholds — pca_multithreshold
text: function generates multi-scale spatial predictors applying PCA distance matrices different neighborhood scales. process distance threshold: Converts distance matrix weights using weights_from_distance_matrix(), distances threshold set zero Applies pca() weighted distance matrix extract principal components Names resulting predictors distance threshold identification Filters predictors near-zero values Multi-scale spatial modeling: Different distance thresholds capture spatial patterns different scales. Combining predictors multiple thresholds allows rf_spatial() account spatial autocorrelation operating multiple spatial scales simultaneously. analogous mem_multithreshold() uses PCA instead Moran's Eigenvector Maps. Comparison MEMs: pca_multithreshold() mem_multithreshold() generate spatial predictors distance matrices, differ approach: PCA: Captures main patterns variation weighted distance matrix without considering spatial autocorrelation structure MEMs: Explicitly extracts spatial patterns specific autocorrelation scales (positive negative eigenvalues) practice, MEMs generally preferred spatial modeling explicitly target spatial autocorrelation patterns, PCA can serve simpler alternative comparison.

title: Visualize spatial cross-validation results — plot_evaluation

title: Visualize variable importance scores — plot_importance

Higher values indicate important variables. Importance computed --bag (OOB) samples, providing unbiased estimate variable contribution. Spatial predictors: rf_spatial() models, spatial predictors (MEMs PCA factors) grouped single category labeled "spatial_predictors" simplify comparison non-spatial predictors. Note violin plots: Violin plots display kernel density estimates. median line shown median density estimate, may differ slightly actual data median. However, variables always ordered true median importance ensure accurate ranking. title: Ranks spatial predictors — rank_spatial_predictors
text: Ranks spatial predictors generated mem_multithreshold() pca_multithreshold() effect reducing Moran's model residuals (ranking.method = "effect"), Moran's (ranking.method = "moran"). former case, one model type y ~ predictors + spatial_predictor_X fitted per spatial predictor, Moran's model's residuals compared one model without spatial predictors (y ~ predictors), finally rank spatial predictor maximum minimum difference Moran's . latter case, spatial predictors ordered Moran's alone (faster option). cases, spatial predictors redundant others Pearson correlation > 0.5 spatial predictors effect (reduction Moran's  Moran's spatial predictor equal lower 0) removed. function designed used internally rf_spatial() rather directly user.

title: Ranks spatial predictors — rank_spatial_predictors
code: rank_spatial_predictors(   data = NULL,   dependent.variable.name = NULL,   predictor.variable.names = NULL,   distance.matrix = NULL,   distance.thresholds = NULL,   ranger.arguments = NULL,   spatial.predictors.df = NULL,   ranking.method = c("moran", "effect"),   reference.moran.i = 1,   verbose = FALSE,   n.cores = parallel::detectCores() - 1,   cluster = NULL )

title: Ranks spatial predictors — rank_spatial_predictors
text: data Data frame response variable set predictors. Default: NULL dependent.variable.name Character string name response variable. Must column names data. Default: NULL predictor.variable.names Character vector names predictive variables. Every element vector must column names data. Default: NULL distance.matrix Squared matrix distances among records data. number rows distance.matrix data must . provided, computation Moran's residuals omitted. Default: NULL distance.thresholds Numeric vector neighborhood distances. distances distance matrix value dustance.thresholds set 0 computation Moran's . NULL, defaults seq(0, max(distance.matrix), length.= 4). Default: NULL ranger.arguments List ranger arguments. See rf rf_repeat details. spatial.predictors.df Data frame spatial predictors. ranking.method Character, method used rank spatial predictors. method "effect" ranks spatial predictors according much predictor reduces Moran's model residuals, method "moran" ranks Moran's . Default: "moran". reference.moran.Moran's residuals model without spatial predictors. Default: 1 verbose Logical, ff TRUE, messages plots generated execution function displayed, Default: TRUE n.cores Integer, number cores use parallel execution. Creates socket cluster parallel::makeCluster(), runs operations parallel foreach %dopar%, stops cluster parallel::clusterStop() job done. Default: parallel::detectCores() - 1 cluster cluster definition generated parallel::makeCluster(). provided, overrides n.cores. cluster = NULL (default value), model provided, cluster model, , used instead. cluster NULL, function uses n.cores instead. function stop provided cluster, stopped parallel::stopCluster() afterwards. cluster definition stored output list name "cluster" can passed functions via model argument, using %>% pipe. Default: NULL

title: Ranks spatial predictors — rank_spatial_predictors
text: list four slots: method: Character, name method used rank spatial predictors. criteria: Data frame two different configurations depending ranking method. ranking.method = "effect", columns contain names spatial predictors, r-squared model, Moran's model residuals, difference Moran's model including given spatial predictor, Moran's model fitted without spatial predictors, interpretation Moran's value. ranking.method = "moran", name spatial predictor Moran's output data frame. ranking: Ordered character vector names spatial predictors selected. spatial.predictors.df: data frame selected spatial predictors order ranking.

title: Ranks spatial predictors — rank_spatial_predictors
code: if(interactive()){  data(   plants_df,   plants_response,   plants_distance )  #subset to speed up example idx <- 50:90 plants_distance_sub <- plants_distance[idx, idx]  y <- mem(   distance.matrix = plants_distance_sub,   distance.threshold = 1000 )  #rank spatial predictors by Moran's I y_rank <- rank_spatial_predictors(   distance.matrix = plants_distance_sub,   distance.thresholds = 1000,   spatial.predictors.df = y,   ranking.method = "moran",   n.cores = 1 )  y_rank$criteria y_rank$ranking  #rank spatial predictors by association with response y_rank <- rank_spatial_predictors(   data = plants_df[idx, ],   dependent.variable.name = plants_response,   distance.matrix = plants_distance_sub,   distance.thresholds = 1000,   spatial.predictors.df = y,   ranking.method = "effect",   n.cores = 1 )  y_rank$criteria y_rank$ranking  }

title: Random forest models with Moran's I test of the residuals — rf
code: rf(   data = NULL,   dependent.variable.name = NULL,   predictor.variable.names = NULL,   distance.matrix = NULL,   distance.thresholds = NULL,   xy = NULL,   ranger.arguments = NULL,   scaled.importance = FALSE,   seed = 1,   verbose = TRUE,   n.cores = parallel::detectCores() - 1,   cluster = NULL )

title: Random forest models with Moran's I test of the residuals — rf
text: data Data frame response variable set predictors. Default: NULL dependent.variable.name Character string name response variable. Must column name data. binary response variables (0/1), case weights automatically computed using case_weights() balance classes. Default: NULL predictor.variable.names Character vector predictor variable names. names must columns data. Alternatively, accepts output auto_cor() auto_vif() automated variable selection. Default: NULL distance.matrix Square matrix pairwise distances observations data. Must number rows data. NULL, spatial autocorrelation residuals computed. Default: NULL distance.thresholds Numeric vector distance thresholds spatial autocorrelation analysis. threshold, distances value set zero computing Moran's . NULL, defaults seq(0, max(distance.matrix), length.= 4). Default: NULL xy Data frame matrix two columns containing coordinates, named "x" "y". used function stored model use rf_evaluate() rf_tuning(). Default: NULL ranger.arguments Named list ranger arguments. Arguments function can also passed . default importance method 'permutation' instead ranger's default 'none'. x, y, formula arguments supported. See ranger help available arguments. Default: NULL scaled.importance TRUE, variable importance computed scaled data using scale, making importance scores comparable across models different predictor units. Default: FALSE seed Random seed reproducibility. Default: 1 verbose TRUE, display messages plots execution. Default: TRUE n.cores Number cores parallel execution. Default: parallel::detectCores() - 1 cluster Cluster object parallel::makeCluster(). used function stored model use downstream functions. Default: NULL

title: Random forest models with Moran's I test of the residuals — rf
text: ranger model object additional slots: ranger.arguments: Arguments used fit model. importance: List global importance data frame (predictors ranked importance), importance plot, local importance scores (per-observation difference accuracy permuted non-permuted predictors, based --bag data). performance: Model performance metrics including R-squared (--bag standard), pseudo R-squared, RMSE, NRMSE. residuals: Model residuals normality diagnostics (residuals_diagnostics()) spatial autocorrelation (moran_multithreshold()).

title: Fits spatial random forest models — rf_spatial
text: function uses three different methods generate spatial predictors ("hengl", "pca", "mem"), two methods rank order define order introduced model ("effect" "moran), two methods select spatial predictors minimize spatial correlation model residuals ("sequential" "recursive"). method names "hengl" (uses complete distance matrix predictors spatial model) named combining method generate spatial predictors, method rank , method select , separated point. Examples "mem.moran.sequential" "mem.effect.recursive". combinations possible, since ranking method "moran" used selection method "recursive" (logics behind different, see ). Methods generate spatial predictors: "hengl": named method RFsp presented paper "Random forest generic framework predictive modeling spatial spatio-temporal variables", Hengl et al. (2018), authors propose use distance matrix among records predictors spatial random forest models (RFsp method). function, methods starting "hengl" use either complete distance matrix, select columns distance matrix spatial predictors. "mem": Generates Moran's Eigenvector Maps, , eigenvectors double-centered weights distance matrix. method described "Spatial modelling: comprehensive framework principal coordinate analysis neighbour matrices (PCNM)", Dray et al. (2006), "Statistical methods temporal space–time analysis community composition data", Legendre Gauthier (2014). "pca": Computes spatial predictors principal component analysis weighted distance matrix (see weights_from_distance_matrix()). experimental method, use caution. Methods rank spatial predictors (see rank_spatial_predictors()): "moran": Computes Moran's spatial predictor, selects ones positive values, ranks higher lower Moran's . "effect": given non-spatial random forest model defined y = p1 + ... + pn, p1 + ... + pn set predictors, every spatial predictor generated (spX) spatial model y = p1 + ... + pn + spX fitted, Moran's residuals computed. spatial predictors ranked much help reduce spatial autocorrelation non-spatial spatial model. Methods select spatial predictors: "sequential" (see select_spatial_predictors_sequential()): spatial predictors added one one order ranked, spatial predictors introduced, best first n predictors selected. method similar one employed MEM methodology (Moran's Eigenvector Maps) described paper "Spatial modelling: comprehensive framework principal coordinate analysis neighbour matrices (PCNM)", Dray et al. (2006), "Statistical methods temporal space–time analysis community composition data", Legendre Gauthier (2014). method generally introduces tens predictors model, usually offers good results. "recursive" (see select_spatial_predictors_recursive()): method tries find smallest combination spatial predictors reduce spatial correlation model's residuals . algorithm goes follows: 1. first ranked spatial predictor introduced model; 2. remaining predictors ranked using "effect" method, using model 1. reference. first spatial predictor resulting ranking introduced model, steps 1. 2. repeated spatial predictors stop effect reducing Moran's model residuals. method takes longer compute, generates smaller sets spatial predictors. experimental method, use caution. ranking procedure completed, algorithm used select minimal subset spatial predictors reduce Moran's residuals: new spatial predictor introduced model, Moran's residuals, p-value, binary version p-value (0 < 0.05 1 >= 0.05), R-squared model, penalization linear number spatial predictors introduced (computed (1 / total spatial predictors) * introduced spatial predictors) rescaled 0 1. , optimization criteria computed max(1 - Moran's , p-value binary) + (weight.r.squared * R-squared) - (weight.penalization.n.predictors * penalization). predictors first one one highest optimization criteria selected best ones reducing spatial correlation model residuals, used along data fit final spatial model.

title: Finds optimal combinations of spatial predictors — select_spatial_predictors_recursive
text: Selects spatial predictors following steps: Gets spatial predictors ranked rank_spatial_predictors() fits model form y ~ predictors + best_spatial_predictor_1. Moran's residuals model used reference value next step. remaining spatial predictors introduced rank_spatial_predictors(), spatial predictor highest ranking introduced new model form y ~  predictors + best_spatial_predictor_1 + best_spatial_predictor_2. Steps 1 2 repeated Moran's improve number repetitions equal 20 percent total number spatial predictors introduced function. method allows select smallest set spatial predictors largest joint effect reducing spatial correlation model residuals, maintaining model's R-squared high possible. consequence running rank_spatial_predictors() iteration, method includes less spatial predictors final model sequential method implemented select_spatial_predictors_sequential() , minimizing spatial correlation maximizing R squared model much possible.

title: Finds optimal combinations of spatial predictors — select_spatial_predictors_recursive
text: algorithm works follows. function rank_spatial_predictors() returns 10 ranked spatial predictors (sp1 sp10, sp7 best one), select_spatial_predictors_recursive() going first fit model y ~ predictors + sp7. , spatial predictors sp2 sp9 ranked rank_spatial_predictors() using model y ~ predictors + sp7 reference (stage, spatial predictors might dropped due lack effect). new ranking spatial predictors ready (say sp5, sp3, sp4), best one (sp5) included model y ~ predictors + sp7 + sp5, remaining ones go rank_spatial_predictors() repeat process spatial predictors depleted.

title: Finds optimal combinations of spatial predictors — select_spatial_predictors_recursive
code: if (interactive()) {   data(     plants_df,     plants_response,     plants_predictors,     plants_distance,     plants_rf   )    #subset to speed up example   idx <- 1:20   plants_df <- plants_df[idx, ]   plants_distance <- plants_distance[idx, idx]    #generate spatial predictors   mems <- mem_multithreshold(     distance.matrix = plants_distance,     distance.thresholds = 100   )    #rank them from higher to lower moran   mems.rank <- rank_spatial_predictors(     ranking.method = "moran",     spatial.predictors.df = mems,     reference.moran.i = plants_rf$residuals$autocorrelation$max.moran,     distance.matrix = plants_distance,     distance.thresholds = 100,     n.cores = 1   )    #select best subset via sequential addition   selection <- select_spatial_predictors_recursive(     data = plants_df,     dependent.variable.name = plants_response,     predictor.variable.names = plants_predictors,     distance.matrix = plants_distance,     distance.thresholds = 0,     spatial.predictors.df = mems,     spatial.predictors.ranking = mems.rank,     ranger.arguments = list(num.trees = 30),     n.cores = 1   )    #names of selected spatial predictors   selection$best.spatial.predictors    #optimization plot   plot_optimization(selection$optimization) }

title: Suggest variable interactions and composite features for random forest models — the_feature_engineer
text: Suggests candidate variable interactions composite features able improve predictive accuracy data used train model via spatial cross-validation rf_evaluate(). pair predictors b, interactions build via multiplication (* b), composite features built extracting first factor principal component analysis performed pca(), rescaling b 1 100. Interactions composite features named ..x..b ..pca..b respectively. Candidate variables b selected predictors predictor.variable.names variable importance importance.threshold (set default median importance scores). interaction composite feature, model including predictors plus interaction composite feature fitted, R squared (AUC response binary) computed via spatial cross-validation (see rf_evaluate()) compared R squared model without interactions composite features. potential interactions screened, positive increase R squared (AUC response binomial) model, variable importance median, maximum correlation among predictors predictor.variable.names higher cor.threshold (set 0.5 default) selected. restrictive set rules ensures selected interactions can used right away modeling purposes without increasing model complexity unnecessarily. However, suggested variable interactions might make sense domain expertise standpoint, please, examine care. function returns criteria used select interactions, data required use interactions model.

code: if (interactive()) {   data(     plants_df,     plants_response,     plants_predictors,     plants_xy,     plants_rf   )    #get five most important predictors from plants_rf to speed-up example   predictors <- get_importance(plants_rf)[1:5, "variable"]    #subset to speed-up example   idx <- 1:30   plants_df <- plants_df[idx, ]   plants_xy <- plants_xy[idx, ]    #data subsetted to speed-up example runtime   y <- the_feature_engineer(     data = plants_df,     dependent.variable.name = plants_response,     predictor.variable.names = predictors,     xy = plants_xy,     repetitions = 5,     n.cores = 1,     ranger.arguments = list(       num.trees = 30     ),     verbose = TRUE   )    #all tested interactions   y$screening    #selected interaction (same as above in this case)   y$selected    #new column added to data   head(y$data[, y$selected$interaction.name]) }

Version 1.1.5
text: CRAN release: 2025-12-19 Fixed Windows-specific error get_response_curves(), plot_response_curves(), rf_evaluate(), rf() predict() method dispatch failed find predict.ranger(). Added @importFrom ranger ranger ensure ranger’s namespace loaded S3 methods properly registered. Code quality improvements: fixed 129 linting issues identified jarl linter, including inefficient vector logic operators statements (| → ||, & → &&), redundant equality comparisons (== TRUE → direct boolean), corrected two bugs .exit() calls weren’t properly restoring user options. Fixed error Error validate_prop(value, prop, check_fun, check_values, reset_na) : check_fun(value) TRUE generated huxtable::set_all_borders(TRUE). Fixed warning “Using size aesthetic lines deprecated ggplot2 3.4.0. ℹ Please use linewidth instead.” produced outdated calls geom_line(). Fixed issue deprecated argument draw_quantiles geom_violin(). Replaced deprecated calls ggplot2::aes_string() ggplot2::aes() plus .data[[whatever]]. Fixed parallelization issues zombi processess across functions. Added internal helper function setup_parallel_execution() centralize improve parallel backend management across functions. Now properly detects respects user-configured backends (via future, doParallel, etc.) maintaining support external internal cluster objects. Refactored cluster setup code across parallelized functions (rf_spatial(), rf_evaluate(), rf_tuning(), rf_repeat(), rf_compare(), rf_importance(), the_feature_engineer(), select_spatial_predictors_sequential(), select_spatial_predictors_recursive()) use new helper, improving consistency reducing code duplication. Removed (interactive()){} wrappers function examples ensure examples run R CMD check. Function rf_spatial() now fits spatial model even ’s necessary. Simplified auto_cor() auto_vif() unified sequential evaluation algorithm better preserves user preference order.

title: Version 1.1.4 (19/08/2022)
text: CRAN release: 2022-08-19 Re-submission, fixes CRAN checks arising invalid links.

title: Version 1.1.3 (22/9/2021)
text: CRAN release: 2021-09-23 Added function rf_importance(). fits models without predictor, compares via spatial cross validation rf_evaluate(), returns increase/decrease performance given variable included model. default random seed functions changed NULL 1 facilitate reproducibility. function rf_evaluate() new argument named grow.testing.folds. set TRUE, uses 1 - training.fraction instead training.fraction grow spatial folds, flips names training testing folds. result, testing folds generally surrounded training folds (just opposite default behavior function), might beneficial particular spatial structures training data. Thanks Aleksandra Kulawska suggestion!

title: Version 1.1.2 (1/7/2021)
text: Overhaul methods used parallelization. functions rf_spatial(), rf_repeat(), rf_evaluate(), rf_tuning(), rf_compare(), rf_interactions() can now accept cluster definition generated parallel::makeCluster() via cluster argument. Also, models resulting functions rf() carry cluster definition slot model$cluster, cluster definition can passed function function using pipe, shown : system works follows: cluster NULL model provided, function looks model. cluster definition , used parallelize computations, cluster stopped within function. cluster model, function falls back argument n.cores generate cluster stopped function ends operations. changes improve performance working several functions script, becuase functions waste time generating clusters. function rf_interactions() now named the_feature_engineer(). function cluster_definition() now named beowulf_cluster(), returns cluster instead cluster definition used input parallel::makeCluster().
code: library(spatialRF) library(magrittr)  #loading the example data data(plant_richness_df) data("distance_matrix") xy <- plant_richness_df[, c("x", "y")] dependent.variable.name <- "richness_species_vascular" predictor.variable.names <- colnames(plant_richness_df)[5:21]   #creating cluster my.cluster <- parallel::makeCluster(   4,   type = "PSOCK" )  #registering cluster (rf functions register it anyway) doParallel::registerDoParallel(cl = cluster)    #fitting model   m <- rf(     data = plant_richness_df,     dependent.variable.name = dependent.variable.name,     predictor.variable.names = predictor.variable.names,     distance.matrix = distance_matrix,     xy = xy,     cluster = my.cluster   ) %>%   rf_spatial() %>%   rf_tuning() %>%   rf_evaluate() %>%   rf_repeat()  #stopping cluster parallel::stopCluster(cl = my.cluster)

title: Version 1.1.1 (11/5/2021)
text: rf_repeat() now generates proper “importance” slot models fitted rf_spatial(), preserves “evaluation” “tuning” slots exist. Simplified rf_spatial() removing options generate rf_repeat() model fly. rf_repeat() used now end workflow, described documentation. Fixed issue area violin plots generated plot_importance(). Improved function rf_interactions() new type interaction (first factor PCA two predictors), added criteria reduce multicollinearity among interactions, interactions predictors, now function returns data helpful fit models right away.

title: Version 1.1.0 (6/5/2021)
text: Added new residuals diagnostics functions residuals_diagnostics() plot_residuals_diagnostics(). changed name slot “spatial.autocorrelation.residuals” “residuals”, now stores information relative residuals. plotting functions now allow change color key components.

title: Version 1.0.9 (20/4/2021)
text: Changed names function arguments ‘x’ ‘model’ ‘distance.matrix’ consistency. might break code written previously, hope argument names self-explanatory now. function rf_spatial() now fits non-spatial model first, generates spatial predictors distance.thresholds show positive spatial autocorrelation.

title: Version 1.0.8 (16/4/2021)
text: Added new function named filter_spatial_predictors(), removes redundant spatial predictors within rf_spatial(). shouldn’t lead changes spatial models fitted previous versions, make parsimonious. Changed style package’s boxplots. using rf_repeat(), median variable importance scores, performance scores, Moran’s reported, instead mean.

title: Version 1.0.7 (9/3/2021)
text: Added functions plot_training_data() plot_moran_training_data() help explore training data prior modeling. Also fixed issue response variables identified binary mistake.

title: Version 1.0.6 (9/3/2021)
text: bug regarding predictions generated rf() affected every function fitting models fixed. Previously, model predictions came “predictions” slot produced ranger(). predictions produced --bag data model training, different lead lower R squared values produced predict(). Now predictions yielded rf() generated predict(), therefore might notice now models fitted spatialRF functions perform better , . function print_evaluation() use huxtable longer print evaluation results, shows results testing model.

title: Version 1.0.5 (6/3/2021)
text: Added support binary data (0 1). function rf() now tests data binary, , populates case.weights argument ranger new function case_weights() minimize side effects unbalanced data.
